comments.commentBody: So how do you know that the person now sitting in the stall next to yours isn't a transgendered woman- or, for that matter, a man?  It's not as though they're presently wearing signs announcing themselves.   This is like the canard concerning "election fraud": conservatives are determined to solve problems that exist only in their imaginations.

There is something fundamentally dishonest about this statement.

It argues that our GITMO policy is a motivator. However, I suspect that the people in the Middle East are a lot more upset about the wanton killing of innocents and the destruction of whole societies by forces which seek first and foremost the control of the oil fields and to a lesser extent the opium fields.

If America were really the Good Knight, doing nothing more than helping the oppressed people of the world find a better life, and if this involved locking a few hundred people in cages half-way around the world, I doubt very much that it would cause very much Jihad.

We need our politicians to tell the truth. We need our politicians to come clean that the reason why the world is in such a mess, and in this I include the US national economy, is because we are spending way too much on destruction and not nearly enough on construction.

If you provide a man with a warm home and a cold refrigerator, he will have very little reason to fight. On the other hand, if you kill his grandmother and his children, well then you're going to have a problem on your hands. The kind of problem no number of cages in the Caribbean will solve.

President Obama's current solution is to just drone these guys to death, along with anyone within a 100 yards. The President's take no prisoner’s policy has cleanly and neatly kept the population of Guantanamo from growing. To me, Guantanamo would be a better option than getting obliterated at a wedding along with half my relatives.
I'm sure the Castro brothers could make good use of a such a facility while our brand spanking new embassy staff full of Obama hand picked internationalistas turn a blind eye.
Close the prison and return the whole base back to Cuba.
Security is always expensive Diane but lets compare it with the cost of High Speed Rail with which the next two generations of Californians will be saddled.

The U.S. has always taken the moral high ground in rhetoric. So, that's the reason why closing the punitive prison -which operates without giving detainees a chance of a criminal trial- is so imperative.

So... it really is "those people". That is to say your "those people" rather than the others' "those people" that Dr. Krugman often conveyrs. For you imply that this sad trend in mortality is exclusively due to "those people" who have been "oting against their own interests", which is code for calling the victims racist fools. I guess you've seen data that shows you that among 45-54 year old white non-Hispanics who vote Democrat (or at least don't vote for Republicans) the mortality rate has not increased. Or you're just making stuff up.

Guantanamo is an epic fail for every American.  It's a true punch in the face of Lady Liberty.  It is the worst use of our governmental powers since we sent Americans to Manzanar for being racially Japanese.  Hindsight allows us to see it plainly.  It's big government run amok.  I lost a friend on flight 11 and a cousin in Afghanistan, so please don't tell me they died so we could act like monsters in front of the whole world.  We're still holding five co-conspirators of 9/11 and haven't moved them towards trial.  This article should tell us why or it isn't completely newsworthy.  10 have been charged or convicted resulting in light sentences, appeals and some have been overturned, which probably translates to: all should be overturned.  The only reason this continues to fester is our current congress is unwilling to let any meaningful legislature pass while our current president is in office.  Those are their words - not mine and they don't mind that you and I are stuck paying the bill.  It always so amazing how fiscal concerns seem to vanish when military profiteers control the events.  If Paul Ryan were half the man he thinks he is - he'd find his way across town and make a deal with the president to close Guantanamo right away.  That would be leadership.  My cousin had heroic dreams of what it meant to him to be an American.  He signed up to defend those dreams.  Keeping this cesspool open makes a mockery of his sacrifice.

The Senate must retake its soul. Put some steel in their backbone.  John and Dianne start stopping money that is important to those who desire to keep the Gulag going. Try a filibuster, get mean.  Treat GTMO as is if it is the Hanoi Hilton, John.  Earn your heroism again!

Senator,
I feel your pain...having gone to bed every night since 2002 till today haunted with desire to close Guantanamo must be terribly trying for you.

I'm sure you can get Mrs Clinton to swear this is a top priority like it was for Obama in 2008 and in 2012, knowing that once elected, this topic will go away for 8 years until you raise it again.

Or, perhaps, your rant is a ruse.

While we're at it, how about bringing Ed Snowden home to a hero's welcome. Or at least drop the draconian charges against him. Senator Feinstein, you don't seem to realize that YOU are part of the problem, not part of the solution. Let's keep Gitmo open and move the Bush and Obama administration war criminals there. We could start with Brennan, whose CIA spied on your Senate investigation committee and tortured, and then with Clapper, Alexander and Hayden of the NSA who all blatantly and boldly lied to Congress many times, and spied on all of us. You Sen. Feinstein, have about as much credibility as those liars do.
Let's move on from Gantanimo. Give it back to Cuba. We got better stuf to do.
What took you so long to come to this conclusion?
What could be more reasonable, humane, moral, and politically savy? Duh!

The best way to cut the Gordian Knot is to close the entire Guantanamo Base and return it fully to Cuba. At the same time, a process of closing more of the 800 or so military bases scattered in other countries should begin. Okinawa could be second in line.

Occam's Razor applies here. There are multiple reasons to close the prison, but in short, it is a crime against every law of man.
Once again steam is being discovered and, more than likely, when the steam cloud dissipates it will claim some individuals and the band will play on.

Obama is not wasting political capital on GITMO. When he wants to go around Congress he deftly manages to do so. Besides, his image on defense is weak enough.

If people really want Obama to address their issue, they need to create a Caucus and threaten the president and democratic party with withholding votes. That's the only language heard today.

The claim is that Obama cannot close Gitmo because Congress won't let him. And we know that the current Congress won't pass anything permitting Obama to close it. Or will they? If Obama had the courage, he could call them thusly:

Congress, you tell me that I cannot close Gitmo, because you will not permit any of the prisoners there to be moved to American soil. So here is what I am going to do. On 1 February 2016, I will use my executive powers to close the prison, reassigning everybody there to somewhere else. I will also order that all the gates be unlocked. The remaining people there will be free to go anywhere they are allowed to go, and I am confident that Cuba will find ways to get them off of the island. If you are objecting to this because you find the Gitmo prisoners dangerous, you are free, of course, to pass legislation bringing them to maximum security prisons in the United States in order to stand trial for crimes that they may have committed. If you choose not to do this, then you will bear the responsibility for anything that they do after they leave Gitmo; you will have had your chance. Oh, I do reserve the right to veto anything you might pass that I believe to be unConstitutional or otherwise in violation of the spirit of American freedom.

I've actually done some work in rural parts in the past years. I've found lots of demoralized white and black folks still willing to work (and actually working) for $10/hr and competing vigorously with undocumented Central Americans for every and any job. Just like an economist like Dr. Krugman can show you that we can import deflation or import inflation and that global forces can import or export unemployment, so can we import poverty and despair. We have some very poor neighbors to the south, desperate to make any kind of living away from endemic violence. They, through no nefarious motives, do import poverty and despair.

Val in Brooklyn, NY to Mom in Long Island
I'm no less confused. As a Black woman, born and raised in New Orleans, LA, and a daughter of two people who's childhood's were during Jim Crow, I find the comparison laughable and insulting. The Edit. Bd. needs to re-study history or talk to someone who's been there.

I'm all for extra protection, rights, etc., for anyone being targeted. How could I not be? But, if that's what's needed, wouldn't specially designated facilities be the answer to this? That way everyone's privacy and dignity are respected. And before anyone else tries the "separate but equal" argument against my comment, here's my answer: no skimping on them. Make them as nice or a tad nicer. That way no specter of the past can haunt us.

Honestly, this is ridiculous.

Submitted 11-5-15@1:17 a.m. EST
There's no protection based on sexual orientation under Texas law, or stated expressly in federal law.  So no, "homosexuals" do not already have these protections in Houston.
Again, this bizarre obsession with bathrooms.  What are we, 12?

This statement has me confused.  "It would have given veterans, pregnant women and senior citizens a valuable layer of protection and prohibited discrimination based on race, color, religion and national origin".  Correct me if I'm wrong, but don't all these groups already have federal protections?  Homosexuals already have these protections as well.  The ONLY purpose this law would have served was to give protections based upon gender identity, which was why it failed. IMHO, all these other groups were mixed in to the law to try to make the fact that this is only about gender identity a bit more palatable.  There is no law that can be proposed at this time that will make it ok to mix genders in spaces that have been gender excusive forever. People just don't believe that transgender is or should be a protected class, but make no mistake, this would be far more palatable an idea if you remove the bathroom/locker room issues.
Take the venom out of it and there wouldn't have been any issue. The hate was your best weapon.
Whether this bigotry is bssed in hate or fear, the outcome, legal discrimination, is not legitimate.
So, allowing discrimination against whole groups of people is now a "policy difference"?   Nice misdirection attempt.  Didn't work.

Still waiting for any leftist news outlet NOT to ascribe policy differences to 'hate.'

I suppose the purpose is to delegitimize the opposition but it does dialogue on sensitive matters no good.
Considering that Gandhi was Hindu, not Christian, I could see where he might take offense.

These people are the reason people are leaving churches in droves. One cannot help but remember the words of a great man:

"Call me a Christian, I take great offense. Call me Christ-like and I deem it a great compliment." Mohandas K. Gandhi
Sure they are.  But, I'd be worried about the judgement of your maker--if you're into that sort of thing.  Didn't Jesus preach love?

Europe is not doing great and the sustainability of each of the facets of their post-WWII arrangements is far from assured. Sure, the U.S. could borrow and implement some elements from some European countries. Let's start with nuclear energy (France), but not do the high unemployment + separatism thing like Spain.

He's done that many times, actually: when inflation/the economy starts to take off. Were you looking for his predicted date? Who knows? We'll see it when it arrives, especially when wages start to rise. It's not happening yet.

I'm not talking about companies like Amazon or Google.  I'm talking about the thousands of small businesses that really can't afford to give paid family leave.  Certain European countries like Denmark have a different tax structure than we do.  I'm sorry, i don't need to be taxed more so that everyone family in America can have paid family time.

The U.S. Department of Defense recently wasted $43 million dollars building a single gas station in Afghanistan that no one will use.

Perhaps your taxes don't need to be raised at all.

http://time.com/money/4096655/43-million-gas-station-afghanistan/

I agree with you.  And the use of the word "stress" changes from person to person, sub-culture to sub-culture.  When my single mom raised three kids and worked full-time she didn't have the word "stress" at her disposal--it wasn't used in the same way then. Now we are all jumping on the bandwagon to say we are stressed.  Let's help those less fortunate and keep the balls in the air.  It's never been easy.

This article is very white and upper middle class sided; Pew Research found that white parents were more than 10 percentage points more likely to express stress than nonwhite parents and that college educated parents and white parents were significantly more likely than other parents to say work life balance is difficult.

HA.I seriously doubt it. Pew Research needs to start knocking on some more doors because that survey was severely misrepresented.

We need to hear the experiences of minority families - Asian, African American, Indian, HIspanic, Native American. I'm sure we might hear how challenging income and education inequality is for them and how they struggle to pay the rent and just get their kids to stay in school.

But no, instead the article features a middle class white family who is tired and just can't quite balance it all. Paid family leave? Please. That's a privilege not a right. The majority of businesses can't afford that.

If you can't have it all - don't have it all. We don't want to hear you complain about it.
